{{Other uses}} {{pp-semi-indef}} {{automatic Taxobox | name = Puffin | image = Puffin002.jpg | image_width = 250px | image_caption = [[Atlantic puffin]]s (''F. arctica'') | fossil_range = [[Pleistocene]] - [[Holocene]], {{fossilrange|0.1|0}} | taxon = Fratercula | authority = [[Mathurin Jacques Brisson|Brisson]], 1760 | type_species = ''[[Alca arctica]]'' | type_species_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]] | subdivision_ranks = [[Species]] | subdivision = ''[[Atlantic puffin|F. arctica]]''
''[[Tufted puffin|F. cirrhata]]''
''[[Horned puffin|F. corniculata]]''
{{extinct}}''[[Dow's puffin|F. dowi]]'' | synonyms = ''Lunda''
''Sagmatorrhina'' Bonaparte, 1851 }} '''Puffins''' are any of three small species of alcids ([[auk]]s) in the [[bird]] genus ''Fratercula'' with a brightly coloured beak during the breeding season. These are [[pelagic zone|pelagic]] [[seabird]]s that feed primarily by diving in the water. They breed in large [[Bird colony|colonies]] on coastal cliffs or offshore islands, nesting in crevices among rocks or in burrows in the soil. Two species, the [[tufted puffin]] and [[horned puffin]], are found in the [[North Pacific Ocean]], while the [[Atlantic puffin]] is found in the North Atlantic Ocean. All puffin species have predominantly black or black and white plumage, a stocky build, and large [[beak]]s. They shed the colourful outer parts of their bills after the breeding season, leaving a smaller and duller beak. Their short wings are adapted for swimming with a flying technique under water. In the air, they beat their wings rapidly (up to 400 times per minute){{cite web | url = http://www.projectpuffin.org/PuffinQuestions.html#9. | title = 26 Questions About Puffins | work = Project Puffin | publisher = National Audubon Society | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120829074845/http://projectpuffin.org/PuffinQuestions.html#9. | archivedate = 2012-08-29 | df = }} in swift flight, often flying low over the ocean's surface. A significant decline in numbers of puffins on [[Shetland]] is worrying scientists.[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jun/20/a-world-without-puffins-the-uncertain-fate-of-the-much-loved-seabirds A world without puffins? The uncertain fate of the much-loved seabirds], Louise Tickle, theguardian.com, 20 June 2018 ==Taxonomy== The [[rhinoceros auklet]] (''Cerorhinca monocerata'') has sometimes been included in the genus ''Fratercula'',{{cite journal |last=Barrows |first=Walter Bradford |year=1877 |title= Family Alcidae|journal=Proceedings of the Boston Society for Natural History |volume=19 |issue= |pages=154 |url= |format= |doi= |quote=}} and some authors place the tufted puffin in the genus ''Lunda''.Harrison (1988) p. 406 The puffins and the rhinoceros auklet are closely related, together composing the subfamily Fraterculini. The [[scientific name]] ''Fratercula'' is derived from [[Latin]] and means "little brother", a reference to the black and white plumage, which resembles [[monasticism|monastic]] robes.{{cite book | last= Jobling | first= James A | year= 2010| title= The Helm Dictionary of Scientific Bird Names | publisher= Christopher Helm | location = London | isbn = 978-1-4081-2501-4 | page = 164}} The English name "puffin" – puffed in the sense of swollen – was originally applied to the fatty, salted meat of young birds of the unrelated [[Manx shearwater]] (''Puffinus puffinus''), formerly known as the "Manks puffin".{{cite book |title=The Oxford Dictionary of British Bird Names |last=Lockwood |first= W. B. |year=1993 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-866196-2|page=100}} Puffin is an Anglo-Norman word ([[Middle English]] ''pophyn'' or ''poffin'') for the cured carcasses of nestling Manx shearwaters.{{OED|Puffin}} The oldest alcid fossil is ''Hydrotherikornis'' from Oregon dating to the Late Eocene while fossils of ''Aethia'' and ''Uria'' go back to the Late Miocene. [[Molecular clocks]] have been used to suggest an origin in the Pacific in the Paleocene.Sergio L. Pereira, Allan J. Baker (2008) "DNA evidence for a Paleocene origin of the Alcidae (Aves: Charadriiformes) in the Pacific and multiple dispersals across northern oceans". ''Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution''; 46:430–445 [http://individual.utoronto.ca/sergiolp/pdf/MPE2008.pdf PDF]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Fossils from North Carolina were originally thought to have been of two ''Fratercula'' species,Olson, S. L.; [[Pamela C. Rasmussen|Rasmussen P.]] (2001) "Miocene and Pliocene birds from the Lee Creek Mine, North Carolina." ''Smithsonian Contributions to Paleobiology'' '''90''' 233-–365. but were later reassigned to one ''Fratercula'', the tufted puffin, and a ''Cerorhinca species''.{{cite journal |last=Smith |first=N. A. |last2=Olson |first2=Storrs L. |last3=Clarke |first3=J. A. |year=2007 |title=First Atlantic Record of the Horned Puffin genus ''Cerorhinca ''(Aves, Alcidae) from the Pliocene of North Carolina |journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |volume=27 |issue=4 |pages=1039–1042 |url=http://si-pddr.si.edu/dspace/bitstream/10088/6544/1/VZ_366_Cerorhinca.pdf |format=PDF |doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2007)27[1039:FAROTP]2.0.CO;2 |quote= |issn=0272-4634 }} Another extinct species, [[Dow's puffin]] (''Fratercula dowi'') was found on the [[Channel Islands of California]] until the [[Late Pleistocene]] or early [[Holocene]].{{cite journal |last=Guthrie |first=Daniel A. |last2=Thomas |first2=Howell W. |last3=Kennedy |first3=George L. |year=1999 |title=A new species of extinct late Pleistocene puffin (Aves: Alcidae) from the southern California Channel Islands |journal=Proceedings of the 5th California Islands Symposium |volume= |issue= |pages=525–530 |url=http://faculty.jsd.claremont.edu/dguthrie/Guthrie.pdf |format=PDF |doi= |quote=}} [[File:Puffin Mrkoww.jpg|thumb|A [[Tufted puffin]] in [[Seattle, Washington]]]] The Fraterculini are thought to have originated in the Pacific primarily because of their greater diversity there; there is only one extant species in the Atlantic, compared to two in the Pacific. The Fraterculini fossil record in the Pacific extends at least as far back as the middle [[Miocene]], with three fossil species of ''Cerorhinca'', and material tentatively referred to that genus, in the middle Miocene to late [[Pliocene]] of southern California and northern Mexico. Although there no records from the Miocene in the Atlantic, a re-examination of the North Carolina material indicated that the diversity of puffins in the early Pliocene was as great in the Atlantic as it is in the Pacific today. This diversity was achieved through influxes of puffins from the Pacific; the later loss of species was due to major oceanographic changes in the late Pliocene due to closure of the Panamanian Seaway and the onset of severe glacial cycles in the North Atlantic. ==Description== The puffins are stocky, short-winged and short-tailed birds, with black upper parts and white or brownish-grey underparts. The head has a black cap, the face is mainly white, and the feet are orange-red. The bill appears large and colourful during the breeding season. The colourful outer part of the bill is shed after the breeding season, revealing a smaller and duller true bill beneath.Harrison (1988) pp. 404–406 Although the puffins are vocal at their breeding colonies, they are silent at sea. They fly relatively high above the water, typically {{convert|10|m|ft|abbr=on}} as compared with the {{convert|1.6|m|ft|abbr=on}} of other auks.Sibley (2000) pp.252–253 {{clear}} ===Species details=== {| width = 98% class="wikitable" ! align="center" style="background-color: #D3D3A4" colspan ="4" |'''Species in [[taxonomic sequence]]''' |- ! width=18% | Common and binomial names ! width=12% | Image ! width=35% | Description ! width=35% |Range |- |[[Atlantic puffin]]

Winters south to [[Honshū]] and California |} ==Behaviour== ===Breeding=== [[File:Puffin falls off cliff.ogv|thumb|Atlantic puffin, [[Lundy]], UK]] [[File:Klippen.jpg|thumb|Atlantic puffins on the [[Faroe Islands]]]] [[File:Iceland - Puffin - Dyrholaey - Road Trip - Chordata (4889976223).jpg|thumb|Puffin in [[Iceland]]]] Puffins breed in colonies on coasts and islands; several current or former island breeding sites are referred to as [[Puffin Island (disambiguation)|Puffin Island]]. The male Atlantic puffin builds the nest and exhibits strong nest-site fidelity. Both sexes of the horned puffin help to construct their nest. Horned puffin burrows are usually about {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} deep, ending in a chamber, while the tunnel leading to a tufted puffin burrow may be up to {{convert|2.75|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} long. The nesting substrate of the tufted and Atlantic puffins is soft soil, into which tunnels are dug; in contrast the nesting sites of horned puffins are rock crevices on cliffs.{{cite web |last2=Kitaysky |first2=Alexander S. |url=http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/603 |title=Horned Puffin (''Fratercula corniculata'') |last=Piatt |first=John F |year=2002 |work=The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). |publisher=Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology |accessdate=1 April 2009 |subscription=yes |doi=10.2173/bna.603}} The Atlantic puffin burrow is usually lined with material such as grass, leaves and feathers but is occasionally unlined. The eggs of the Atlantic puffin are typically creamy white but the odd egg is tinged lilac. Where [[rabbit]]s breed, sometimes Atlantic puffins breed in rabbit burrows. Puffins form long-term pair bonds or relationships. The female lays a single egg, and both parents incubate the egg and feed the chick (or "puffling"{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_8230000/newsid_8236600/8236609.stm|title=Kids patrol to help lost puffins |date=September 3, 2009|work=[[CBBC]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=26 February 2013}}). The incubating parent holds the egg against its [[brood patch]] with its wings. The chicks [[fledge]] at night. After fledging, the chicks spend the first few years of their lives at sea, returning to breed about five years later. Puffins in captivity have been known to breed as early as three years of age. After breeding, all three puffin species winter at sea, usually far from coasts and often extending south of the breeding range. Iceland is the home to most of the [[Atlantic puffin]]s with about 10 million individuals.[http://www.xtreme.is/safnahus/?p=200&s=733&i=762] The largest single puffin colony in the world is in [[Westmann Isles]], islands that belong to [[Iceland]]. In 2009, scientists estimated the number of nests to be 1.1 million,[http://www.nattsud.is/index.php?lang=2&p=200&i=15] and number of individuals there is estimated to be up to 4 million. ===Feeding=== Like many auks, puffins eat both [[fish]] and [[zooplankton]], but feed their chicks primarily with small marine fish several times a day. The prey species of the Atlantic puffin include the [[sand eel|sandeel]], [[herring]] and [[capelin]].Baillie SM & Jones IL 2004. Response of Atlantic puffin ''Fratercula arctica'' to a decline in capelin ''Mallotus villosus'' abundance at the Gannet Islands, Labrador in the late 1990s. ''Waterbirds'' 78(1): 102-111 [http://www.massey.ac.nz/~dhbrunto/ppl/BaillieS/baillieNjones2004.pdf PDF]Simon P. R. Greenstreet, Eric Armstrong, Henrik Mosegaard, Henrik Jensen, Iain M. Gibb, Helen M. Fraser, Beth E. Scott, Gayle J. Holland, and Jonathan Sharples (2006) Variation in the abundance of sandeels ''Ammodytes marinus'' off southeast Scotland: an evaluation of area-closure fisheries management and stock abundance assessment methods. ''ICES J. Mar Sci.'' 63: 1530–1550. The puffins are distinct in their ability to hold several (sometimes over a dozen) small fish at a time, crosswise in their bill, rather than regurgitating swallowed fish. This allows them to take longer [[foraging]] trips, since they can come back with more food energy for their chick than a bird that can only carry one fish at a time. This behaviour is made possible by the unique hinging mechanism of their beak, which allows the upper and lower biting edges to meet at any of a number of angles. ==Relationships with humans== {{See also|Faroese puffin}} ===Hunting=== Puffins are hunted for eggs, feathers and meat. Atlantic puffin populations drastically declined due to habitat destruction and exploitation during the 19th century and early 20th century. They continue to be hunted in Iceland and the Faroe Islands.{{cite web |url=http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/709 |title=Atlantic Puffin (''Fratercula arctica'') |last1=Lowther |first1=Peter E. |last2=Diamond |first2=A. W |last3=Kress |first3=Stephen W. |last4=Robertson |first4=Gregory J. |last5=Russell |first5=Keith |year=2002 |work=The Birds of North America Online |editor-last=Poole |editor-first=A. |publication-place=Ithaca |publisher=Cornell Lab of Ornithology |accessdate=1 April 2009 |subscription=yes |doi=10.2173/bna.709}} On the [[Blasket Islands]] off the coast of [[County Kerry]], which were abandoned in 1953, the islanders, who often lived just above starvation level, hunted and ate puffins in large numbers. The Atlantic puffin forms part of the national diet in Iceland, where the species does not have legal protection. Puffins are hunted by a technique called "sky fishing", which involves catching the puffins in a big net as they dive into the sea. Their meat is commonly featured on hotel menus. The fresh heart of a puffin is eaten raw as a traditional Icelandic delicacy.{{cite news |last=Plunkett |first=John |title=Gordon Ramsay cleared over puffin eating |work=The Guardian, 15 September 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/sep/15/channel4.television |publisher= |accessdate=6 April 2009 |location=London |date=15 September 2008}} On the small Icelandic island of [[Grímsey|Grimsey]] as many as 200 puffins can be caught in a single morning.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-41359122|title=The island where people eat puffins|last=|first=|date=24 September 2017|website=BBC News|access-date=24 September 2017}} ===Related places and products=== {{See also|Puffin Island (disambiguation)}} The name of the English island [[Lundy]] is believed to come from the [[Proto-Norse|old Norse]] word for "puffin island" (Lundey),{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/livingworld_20040606.shtml |title=Puffin Island |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |work=BBC Radio 4 - The Living World }} however an alternative explanation has been suggested with Lund referring to a copse, or wooded area.{{cite web |url=http://www.lundypete.com/lundey.htm |title=Meaning of lundey |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |work=Pete Robson's Lundy Island Site |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929080959/http://www.lundypete.com/lundey.htm |archive-date=September 29, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The Atlantic puffin is the provincial bird of the Canadian province of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]]. File:Stora dimun puffins for kitchen.jpg|Puffins are considered a delicacy on the Faroe Islands File:Faroe stamp 031 puffin.jpg|[[Faroe Islands|Faroese]] stamp of 1978 showing a puffin File:Lundy 1 Puffin 1929 Martin Coles Harman(rev)-4044.jpg|Reverse of "One Puffin" coin, [[Lundy]] 1929 File:Lundy 1-2 Puffin 1929 Martin Coles Harman(rev)-4046.jpg|Reverse of "Half Puffin" coin, [[Lundy]] 1929 ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * Alsop, Fred J. Winters south to [[Honshū]] and California |} ==Behaviour== ===Breeding=== [[File:Puffin falls off cliff.ogv|thumb|Atlantic puffin, [[Lundy]], UK]] [[File:Klippen.jpg|thumb|Atlantic puffins on the [[Faroe Islands]]]] [[File:Iceland - Puffin - Dyrholaey - Road Trip - Chordata (4889976223).jpg|thumb|Puffin in [[Iceland]]]] Puffins breed in colonies on coasts and islands; several current or former island breeding sites are referred to as [[Puffin Island (disambiguation)|Puffin Island]]. The male Atlantic puffin builds the nest and exhibits strong nest-site fidelity. Both sexes of the horned puffin help to construct their nest. Horned puffin burrows are usually about {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} deep, ending in a chamber, while the tunnel leading to a tufted puffin burrow may be up to {{convert|2.75|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} long. The nesting substrate of the tufted and Atlantic puffins is soft soil, into which tunnels are dug; in contrast the nesting sites of horned puffins are rock crevices on cliffs.{{cite web |last2=Kitaysky |first2=Alexander S. |url=http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/603 |title=Horned Puffin (''Fratercula corniculata'') |last=Piatt |first=John F |year=2002 |work=The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). |publisher=Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology |accessdate=1 April 2009 |subscription=yes |doi=10.2173/bna.603}} The Atlantic puffin burrow is usually lined with material such as grass, leaves and feathers but is occasionally unlined. The eggs of the Atlantic puffin are typically creamy white but the odd egg is tinged lilac. Where [[rabbit]]s breed, sometimes Atlantic puffins breed in rabbit burrows. Puffins form long-term pair bonds or relationships. The female lays a single egg, and both parents incubate the egg and feed the chick (or "puffling"{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_8230000/newsid_8236600/8236609.stm|title=Kids patrol to help lost puffins |date=September 3, 2009|work=[[CBBC]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=26 February 2013}}). The incubating parent holds the egg against its [[brood patch]] with its wings. The chicks [[fledge]] at night. After fledging, the chicks spend the first few years of their lives at sea, returning to breed about five years later. Puffins in captivity have been known to breed as early as three years of age. After breeding, all three puffin species winter at sea, usually far from coasts and often extending south of the breeding range. Iceland is the home to most of the [[Atlantic puffin]]s with about 10 million individuals.[http://www.xtreme.is/safnahus/?p=200&s=733&i=762] The largest single puffin colony in the world is in [[Westmann Isles]], islands that belong to [[Iceland]]. In 2009, scientists estimated the number of nests to be 1.1 million,[http://www.nattsud.is/index.php?lang=2&p=200&i=15] and number of individuals there is estimated to be up to 4 million. ===Feeding=== Like many auks, puffins eat both [[fish]] and [[zooplankton]], but feed their chicks primarily with small marine fish several times a day. The prey species of the Atlantic puffin include the [[sand eel|sandeel]], [[herring]] and [[capelin]].Baillie SM & Jones IL 2004. Response of Atlantic puffin ''Fratercula arctica'' to a decline in capelin ''Mallotus villosus'' abundance at the Gannet Islands, Labrador in the late 1990s. ''Waterbirds'' 78(1): 102-111 [http://www.massey.ac.nz/~dhbrunto/ppl/BaillieS/baillieNjones2004.pdf PDF]Simon P. R. Greenstreet, Eric Armstrong, Henrik Mosegaard, Henrik Jensen, Iain M. Gibb, Helen M. Fraser, Beth E. Scott, Gayle J. Holland, and Jonathan Sharples (2006) Variation in the abundance of sandeels ''Ammodytes marinus'' off southeast Scotland: an evaluation of area-closure fisheries management and stock abundance assessment methods. ''ICES J. Mar Sci.'' 63: 1530–1550. The puffins are distinct in their ability to hold several (sometimes over a dozen) small fish at a time, crosswise in their bill, rather than regurgitating swallowed fish. This allows them to take longer [[foraging]] trips, since they can come back with more food energy for their chick than a bird that can only carry one fish at a time. This behaviour is made possible by the unique hinging mechanism of their beak, which allows the upper and lower biting edges to meet at any of a number of angles. ==Relationships with humans== {{See also|Faroese puffin}} ===Hunting=== Puffins are hunted for eggs, feathers and meat. Atlantic puffin populations drastically declined due to habitat destruction and exploitation during the 19th century and early 20th century. They continue to be hunted in Iceland and the Faroe Islands.{{cite web |url=http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/709 |title=Atlantic Puffin (''Fratercula arctica'') |last1=Lowther |first1=Peter E. |last2=Diamond |first2=A. W |last3=Kress |first3=Stephen W. |last4=Robertson |first4=Gregory J. |last5=Russell |first5=Keith |year=2002 |work=The Birds of North America Online |editor-last=Poole |editor-first=A. |publication-place=Ithaca |publisher=Cornell Lab of Ornithology |accessdate=1 April 2009 |subscription=yes |doi=10.2173/bna.709}} On the [[Blasket Islands]] off the coast of [[County Kerry]], which were abandoned in 1953, the islanders, who often lived just above starvation level, hunted and ate puffins in large numbers. The Atlantic puffin forms part of the national diet in Iceland, where the species does not have legal protection. Puffins are hunted by a technique called "sky fishing", which involves catching the puffins in a big net as they dive into the sea. Their meat is commonly featured on hotel menus. The fresh heart of a puffin is eaten raw as a traditional Icelandic delicacy.{{cite news |last=Plunkett |first=John |title=Gordon Ramsay cleared over puffin eating |work=The Guardian, 15 September 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/sep/15/channel4.television |publisher= |accessdate=6 April 2009 |location=London |date=15 September 2008}} On the small Icelandic island of [[Grímsey|Grimsey]] as many as 200 puffins can be caught in a single morning.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-41359122|title=The island where people eat puffins|last=|first=|date=24 September 2017|website=BBC News|access-date=24 September 2017}} ===Related places and products=== {{See also|Puffin Island (disambiguation)}} The name of the English island [[Lundy]] is believed to come from the [[Proto-Norse|old Norse]] word for "puffin island" (Lundey),{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/livingworld_20040606.shtml |title=Puffin Island |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |work=BBC Radio 4 - The Living World }} however an alternative explanation has been suggested with Lund referring to a copse, or wooded area.{{cite web |url=http://www.lundypete.com/lundey.htm |title=Meaning of lundey |accessdate=September 5, 2007 |work=Pete Robson's Lundy Island Site |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929080959/http://www.lundypete.com/lundey.htm |archive-date=September 29, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The Atlantic puffin is the provincial bird of the Canadian province of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]].
